channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: Pennsylvania Stakes Its Claim as Center of the Political Universe
item.description: Few states feature as many high-stakes, competitive races, each pulsing with the political currents that are shaping midterm campaigns across the country.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: President Biden, whose 2020 success in Pennsylvania propelled him to the White House, delivered two speeches in the state this week.

item.title: Price Cap on Russian Oil Wins Backing of G7 Ministers
item.description: The proposal aims to stabilize unsettled energy markets in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. But it faces considerable obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: A crude oil terminal near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia. Energy analysts are skeptical that a proposal to corral the price of Russian oil would be successful.

item.title: I.A.E.A. Head Warns of Grave Risk From Fighting Near Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned that increased fighting near the Russian-occupied nuclear plant could cause an accident.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the I.A.E.A., and a team of inspectors visited the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on Thursday.

item.title: FBI Found Empty Folders That Had Contained Classified Documents at Trump’s Home
item.description: A detailed inventory of items seized in the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago raised the question of whether the government had fully recovered the documents or any remained missing.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A more detailed list of the documents that were seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida was unsealed on Friday.

item.title: With Midterms Looming, McConnell’s Woes Pile Up
item.description: The minority leader who takes pride in his status as the “grim reaper” of his rivals’ agenda has allowed Democrats to claim policy victories as his party’s hopes of reclaiming the Senate dim.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, and a bloc of Republicans in Congress believe they need to win back suburban voters by supporting issues with broad political appeal.

item.title: Barr Dismisses Trump’s Request for a Special Master
item.description: The former attorney general, who chose not to indict Mr. Trump in the Russia inquiry, said the Justice Department was justified in investigating his handling of government materials.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Former Attorney General William P. Barr defended the Justice Department’s search of Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Looks On
item.description: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: The Mother of Serena and Venus Williams, Oracene Price, Is a Force All Her Own
item.description: The mother of Serena and Venus Williams has always been a beacon of calm and grace on the sidelines — even now, in what may be a turning point in her daughters’ lives.
item.dc:creator: Anna Grace Lee
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oracene Price, the mother of Serena Williams, at her daughter’s match against Danka Kovinic at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the first round of women’s singles on the first day of the 2022 U.S. Open.

item.title: U.S. Job Growth Slowed in August
item.description: The monthly employment report suggested that the Federal Reserve might be able to tame inflation without causing a recession.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Investigators Seize 27 Antiquities From the Met, Citing Looting
item.description: The museum said it is cooperating with the Manhattan district attorney’s office, which has executed several search warrants at the museum since February.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg and Graham Bowley

item.title: ‘Magic in Her Hands.’ The Woman Bringing India’s Forests Back to Life
item.description: Tulsi Gowind Gowda has spent most of her more than 80 years planting and nurturing trees in southern India. “I like them more than anything else in my life,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tulsi Gowda has devoted her life to transforming barren land into dense forests in Karnataka, a state in southern India.

item.title: College Football Playoff Will Expand to 12 Teams
item.description: The change could take effect as soon as the 2024 season. It is expected no later than 2026.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:description: Stetson Bennett, quarterback for the University of Georgia, celebrating after winning the College Football Playoff championship this year.

item.title: A Trip Home With Moneybagg Yo, Trap’s New Ambassador
item.description: The 30-year-old artist, whose last album topped the Billboard album chart, has grown into the biggest rap star to emerge from Memphis in a generation. His fifth LP is due this fall.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moneybagg Yo has been releasing music for a decade. With “Federal” in 2015, his mixtapes started garnering wider attention.

item.title: The Founders of a Nation Should Not Have the Last Word
item.description: Chileans are debating how to rewrite the nation’s Constitution to address their society’s most stubborn problems.
item.dc:creator: Binyamin Appelbaum
item.media:credit: Tamara Merino for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erica Gonzalez leads a small group of women in Chile who advocate passage of a new Constitution.

item.title: Amazon Can’t Fix America’s Health Care Crisis
item.description: There is no technological miracle that will fix decades of bad policy.
item.dc:creator: Libby Watson

item.title: Proving Racists Wrong Is Not a Trivial Pursuit
item.description: Underestimation should be countered with demonstration, not indignation.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Connecting to Nature
item.description: School is for nurturing children’s innate talents and helping them figure out where those gifts, necessarily diverse, fit in the whole.
item.dc:creator: Nicolette Sowder
item.media:credit: Stacy Kranitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolette Sowder home-schools her two daughters and two nieces at her family farm near Cedar Springs, Mich.

item.title: Salman Rushdie and What It Means to Support Free Speech
item.description: I felt the power of the rush of readers who ran to the stage when Salman Rushdie was attacked.
item.dc:creator: Henry Reese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: “The Rings of Power” on Amazon Can’t Do J.R.R. Tolkien Justice
item.description: Amazon’s “The Rings of Power” will struggle to recreate the magic of Middle-earth, a world not fit for “cinematic universe” treatment.
item.dc:creator: Michael D.C. Drout
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)
item.media:description: Morfydd Clark in Amazon Studios’ “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.” Not all stories are suited to being expanded and exploited by Hollywood.

item.title: How to Have Fun Again
item.description: An illustrated guide to letting loose.
item.dc:creator: Wendy MacNaughton

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Social Mobility
item.description: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
item.dc:creator: John N. Friedman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; the Met Collection; Jordan Graff and Robo Wunderkind, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose and Vacuumfan7072, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Vancouver’s Unconventional Approach to Its Fentanyl Crisis
item.description: The Canadian city has taken the concept of harm reduction to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Sydney Harper, Jessica Cheung, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Liz O. Baylen, Ben Calhoun, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Chelsea Daniel and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injection supplies at a clinic in Vancouver. The fentanyl dispensary at the clinic is legal, and Canada’s public health system finances it.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: A sweet and mellow comedy wraps its season, and “Rick and Morty” returns.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Club Cumming Presents a Queer Comedy Extravaganza (TV Program)
item.media:description: Esther Smith and Rafe Spall in a scene from the Season 3 finale of “Trying.”

item.title: Money to Burn: Lessons From the Premier League’s Transfer Window
item.description: English teams awash in cash broke records for players and prices this summer, proving again that they operate on a plane apart from their rivals.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Sign the stars, sell the shirts, repeat.

item.title: Argentina Reels From Assassination Attempt on Its Vice President
item.description: The man who the authorities believe tried to shoot Cristina Fernández de Kirchner showed an interest in a mix of fringe ideologies, including the far right, his social media showed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Leonardo Coelho and David Feliba
item.media:description: Argentina’s vice president, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, with her security detail outside her residence in Buenos Aires on Friday.

item.title: Hungry for Cash, Zeldin Turns to Trump in N.Y. Governor’s Race
item.description: Representative Lee Zeldin is depending on Donald J. Trump’s stature to help him in a crucial race for cash, even though Mr. Trump is unpopular in New York.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: For $100,000 a couple, attendees at Representative Lee Zeldin’s fund-raiser this weekend will get time with former President Trump.

item.title: Jane Fonda Says She Has Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
item.description: The actress said that she had begun chemotherapy and vowed not to “let any of this interfere with my climate activism.”
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens, Dani Blum and Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jane Fonda in 2020.

item.title: Pete Buttigieg Is Trying to Fix Air Travel With a ‘Dashboard.’ What’s on It?
item.description: The D.O.T. says its new interactive chart is compelling many U.S. airlines to publicly commit to pay for things like hotels and meals when flights are canceled or significantly delayed. But does it have teeth?
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Paul Hennessy/SOPA Images - LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Travelers look at a display board showing canceled and delayed flights at Orlando International Airport earlier this year.

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness
item.description: New research shows small gestures matter even more than we may think.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: 5 Foam Rolling Exercises for Skeptics
item.description: Here’s what to know before adding a foam roller to your warm-up or cool down.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Abramson
item.media:credit: Monica Dzik for The New York Times

item.title: Overlooked No More: Vera Menchik, First Women’s Chess Champion
item.description: As the only woman in a tournament, she was often greeted with skepticism. She once responded by saying that she looked forward “to drinking some men’s blood.”
item.dc:creator: Gavin Edwards
